An eKanban system sending real-time demand signals and providing 
continuous status updates that are visible throughout the plant, can greatly 
reduce the need for physical interactions and ultimately, variability. 
Building Trust in the System
eKanbans can serve to create one source of truth throughout the system.  As 
eKanban signaling is utilized, the amount of variability throughout the process is 
reduced and each step begins to trust the previous step.  This reduces the need 
to add extra protection everywhere in the supply chain.  eKanban

Document 260: 12
The inputs to MRP (the master schedule, BOM, lead times, purchasing, and 
inventory) frequently change. These frequent changes generate what is called 
system nervousness and can create havoc in purchasing and production 
departments if implemented. OM personnel reduce such nervousness by 
evaluating the need and impact of changes prior to disseminating requests to 
other departments by using two tools: Time fences & Pegging . 
Time fences allow a segment of the master schedule to be designated as “not 
to be rescheduled.”
Pegging means tracing upward in the BOM from the component to the parent 
item. By pegging upward, the production planner can determine the cause for 
the requirement and make a judgment about the necessity for a change in the 
schedule.

Customer Order-Driven, Pull-Based Kanban 
Systems
Pull-based systems represent the other end of the spectrum. Pull systems 
are based on the Toyota Production System (TPS) and its western 
interpretation, “Lean Manufacturing”. The Pull method from TPS is often 
referred to as a Kanban system – a method for planning, execution and 
inventory replenishment that enables flow through greater control.

Document 157: planning and execution that is pushed out from the top.  Plan results are 
adjusted and reported back up the chain. This slow and often arduous 
feedback loop doesn’t offer much flexibility to quickly respond to the inevitable 
variation in customer demand and execution to the plan. Rather, it often leads 
to a negative spiral of adding inventory, clogging up production and leading to 
diminished capacity and loss of control.  This is the very opposite of what we 
are trying to achieve with our systems.

Document 203: 11CONWIP Vs Pure Push System:
CONWIP exhibits the following advantages over a pure 
push system:
•The WIP level is directly observable, while the release rate in a 
push system must be set with respect to (unobservable) capacity.
•It requires less WIP on average to attain the same throughput.
•It facilitates working ahead of a schedule when favorable 
circumstances permit it.
Copyright © 2008 by Wallace J. Hopp and Mark C. Spearman

Document 209: 17Summary
•Push systems schedule the release of work on the basis of 
demand information, while pull systems authorize the release 
of work on the basis of inventory status within the system.
•The “magic” of pull systems is that they establish a WIP cap, which prevents producing unnecessary WIP that does not 
signiﬁcantly improve throughput.
•The simplest mechanism for establishing a WIP cap is 
CONWIP (constant work in process), in which the WIP level 
in a line is held constant by synchronizing releases to departures.
Copyright © 2008 by Wallace J. Hopp and Mark C. Spearman

Push v. Pull Planning and Execution Systems     
in Manufacturing
The contrast between Push and Pull-based systems starts at the planning 
phase. In traditional Push-based MRP/ERP environments, a plan is developed 
and pushed through the system. The assumption for planning in a Push 
environment is that everything remains constant; the company has the 
capacity on hand, along with the inventory and decision support staff to 
execute the plan. And while seemingly proactive, the plan often becomes 
obsolete before it is executed as it cannot easily accommodate changes in 
market conditions or adjust to variations inherent in manufacturing 
environments.  manufacturing so ftware

Document 145: Introduction
This is the first in a series of papers exploring the nature of Pull-based 
manufacturing systems and specifically, Kanban systems. The focus of this 
paper is at the system, or workflow level, while subsequent publications will 
review Pull/Kanban systems from a management, customer and competitive 
standpoint. After reading this paper, you will have a good understanding of 
both Pull and Push-based manufacturing systems and your choices for 
systems within a Pull environment. After reading the collection of papers, you 
should have a 360-degree perspective of the impact of a Pull/Kanban system 
in an organization.

Overlapping is a method that processes part of the lot on the work center 
performing the second operation, while the rest of the lot is still in the work 
center in the first operation. Overlapping reduces lead time in a way similar to 
parallel processing.
Operations Splitting: Throughput time decreases as only part of the lot is 
processed on one machine. 
Lot Splitting /Order Splitting: A lot (or order) is split, and a part of it is run 
ahead of schedule in a period where there is available capacity.

personal productivity Kanbans), in the manufacturing world, we make the 
distinction between manual and electronic – or eKanban software systems.

In time series decomposition, the difference between additive and multiplicative seasonal variation lies in how the seasonal component is combined with the other components. 

- Additive seasonal variation: The forecast including trend is equal to the trend plus the seasonal factor (Forecast including trend and seasonal = Trend + Seasonal factor). This means that the seasonal effect is constant over time.

- Multiplicative seasonal variation: The forecast including trend is equal to the trend multiplied by the seasonal factor (Forecast including trend and seasonal = Trend × Seasonal factor). This implies that the seasonal effect changes with the level of the variable.

For example, in additive seasonality, if the seasonal factor is 100 for a particular season, it will always be 100 for that same season throughout the time series. Meanwhile, in multiplicative seasonality, if the seasonal factor is 1.2 for a particular season, it means that the seasonal effect is 1.2 times the level of the variable during that season, and this factor could change as the level of the variable changes over time.

A firm would use risk-hedging strategies to reduce risk in the face of high levels of supply uncertainty. This can include measures such as hedging currency risks, producing/sourcing locally to mitigate country risks, using multiple suppliers to reduce supplier failure risk, supporting redundant digital networks to mitigate network provider failure risk, obtaining up-front and continuing research, good legal advice, and compliance to mitigate regulatory risk, and using multisource and commodity hedging to mitigate commodity price risks.

Takt Time in operations management is the pace of processing required to match the pace of customer demand. It is calculated by dividing the effective working time per shift by the customer requirement per shift. Takt time sets the rhythm for production and helps determine the required resources to meet demand.

It can be caused by factors such as forward buying and poor communication between supply chain partners.

Yes, the pair of tools used by Operations Management professionals to mitigate the issue of system nervousness are Time Fences and Pegging. Time fences allow a segment of the master schedule to be designated as "not to be rescheduled,” thereby creating a stable area in the face of frequent changes. Pegging, on the other hand, traces upward in the Bill of Materials (BOM) from the component to the parent item. This helps production planners determine the cause for the requirement and make a judgment about the necessity for a change in the schedule.

A 'Bottleneck' in operations management refers to a resource or stage in the production process where capacity is less than the demand placed on it. This constriction directly impacts the overall process capacity, as the system's throughput can only be increased by saving time on bottleneck resources. Bottlenecks can be identified by calculating the expected utilization (percentage of capacity used) for each resource. They are crucial to consider in the Theory of Constraints (TOC) approach to synchronous manufacturing, where managing the flow through these bottlenecks is essential for improving processes and maximizing efficiency.

Sure, in the context of inventory management, the key differences between a Pull and Push-based system are as follows:

1. Release of work: In a Push system, work is released based on demand information, while in a Pull system, work is authorized based on inventory status within the system.
2. Control: Push systems schedule the release of work and control the release rate, while Pull systems control the work in process (WIP) level and observe throughput.
3. Responsiveness vs. inventory: Push systems prioritize responsiveness and are therefore more inventory-intensive, while Pull systems aim to prevent unnecessary production and minimize inventory levels.
4. Execution process: Under the Push method, charging/feeding the system is done by the forecast, while in Pull systems, it is the consumption of inventory that authorizes activity.
5. WIP cap: Pull systems establish a WIP cap, which prevents producing unnecessary WIP that does not significantly improve throughput.
6. Impact of product diversification: The optimal position of the Push/Pull interface depends on the need for responsiveness and the cost of carrying inventory, which is influenced by product diversification.
7. Levers: Product design (postponement) and process design (quick response manufacturing) are levers that can be used to optimize the position of the Push/Pull interface.

In summary, Pull systems are more responsive to actual customer demand and aim to minimize inventory levels, while Push systems are more forecast-driven and inventory-intensive. The choice between the two systems depends on various factors, including the need for responsiveness, the cost of carrying inventory, and the level of product diversification.

Implementing CONWIP over a pure push system in a typical organization that transforms inputs into outputs provides several benefits:

1. Directly observable WIP level: CONWIP makes it easier to monitor the work-in-process (WIP) level, while in a pure push system, the WIP level is not directly observable, and the release rate must be set based on unobservable capacity.

2. Lower WIP levels: CONWIP requires less WIP on average to achieve the same throughput compared to a pure push system.

3. Working ahead of schedule: CONWIP allows organizations to work ahead of a schedule when favorable circumstances arise.

4. Prevents WIP explosions: By implementing a WIP cap, CONWIP helps prevent WIP explosions, reducing costs.

5. Improved quality: CONWIP creates pressure for higher quality and improved defect detection, leading to better overall quality.

6. Improved customer service: CONWIP reduces cycle time variability, encourages shorter lead times, and promotes better on-time performance.

7. Maintains flexibility: CONWIP avoids early releases, reduces direct congestion, and promotes floating capacity, allowing for better adaptation to changes and reduced reliance on forecasts.

8. Control and predictability: CONWIP fosters a culture of working on the system instead of just in it, providing better control and predictability in operations and supply chain management.

In manufacturing environments with frequent changes in market conditions, the primary distinctions between Push and Pull-based systems are as follows:

1. Planning phase: Push systems start with a predefined plan that is developed based on certain assumptions and pushed through the system. In contrast, Pull systems are driven by customer demand and focus on executing the order, allowing for quicker response to changes in demand.

2. Capacity and inventory: Push systems assume constant capacity and inventory, while Pull systems are designed to be more responsive and agile, accommodating variations in market conditions and manufacturing environments.

3. Adaptability: Push systems have limited adaptability to market changes or internal variations, whereas Pull systems are more flexible and can better handle fluctuations in demand and production.

4. Data and analytics: Pull systems provide deeper access to data and analytics, empowering decision-making, and creating a more predictable environment compared to Push systems.

In summary, Push systems are more rigid and less adaptable to changing market conditions, while Pull systems are more responsive and agile, allowing for better alignment with actual customer demand.

This approach is similar to parallel processing in its effect on reducing lead time.

A push system in the context of service quality is one where production or service delivery is initiated without a specific customer order or demand. In this system, intangible differences between products and customer expectations can play a significant role, as there might be a disconnect between what is produced and what customers ultimately want. For example, a "pure" MRP system, where production is based on forecasts, can be considered a push system. Here, the focus is on meeting production goals, and there might be less emphasis on understanding and meeting individual customer expectations.

On the other hand, a pull system is one where production or service delivery is initiated in response to a specific customer order or demand. This system is more responsive to individual customer needs and expectations, as it takes into account real-time demand. For instance, a vending machine is a pull system, where goods are delivered only when a customer makes a specific selection. Here, the intangible differences between products and customer expectations are directly addressed, as the customer has the final say in the product they receive.

In the given document, there is no direct example of a pull system in the context of service quality. However, a steakhouse or girlhouse restaurant can be considered a pull system, where orders are taken based on customer preferences, and food is prepared accordingly. This system addresses intangible differences between products (e.g., doneness of steak) and customer expectations, as the customer can specify their preferences.

In conclusion, while the given document does not provide explicit examples of push and pull systems in the context of service quality, it is possible to infer that a "pure" MRP system is a push system, while a vending machine or restaurant ordering system is a pull system. Both systems are affected by intangible differences between products and customer expectations, but the pull system is more responsive to individual customer needs and expectations.

The CONWIP (Constant Work-In-Progress) model has two main assumptions:
1. Single routing: There is only one route or path for a part or product to follow through the production system.
2. WIP measured in units: The Work-In-Progress (WIP) is measured and controlled in terms of the number of units or jobs in the system.

Additionally, the CONWIP system allows the next job to enter the production line when a job leaves, thus maintaining a constant WIP level of 'm' jobs in the line at all times.

For further comparison, CONWIP exhibits advantages over a pure push system, such as direct observability of WIP level, less WIP required on average for the same throughput, and enabling working ahead of schedule when favorable circumstances occur.

In contrast, MRP (Material Requirements Planning) systems resemble open queueing networks, while CONWIP and Kanban look like closed queueing networks, with Kanban having an additional feature of blocking.

These explanations should help you understand the basics of the CONWIP model.

Little's Law is a mathematical relationship in the context of production process mapping, describing the connection between inventory, throughput, and flow time. Inventory is equal to the throughput rate multiplied by flow time. This relationship helps in understanding and improving the efficiency and performance of a production process.

In Operations and Supply Chain Management, forecasting influences various management decisions across functions. Here are the different types of forecasts:

1. Qualitative Forecasts: These are based on judgment or opinions of experts, using techniques like market research, executive opinions, and the Delphi method. They are often used when historical data is unavailable or quantitative methods are inappropriate.

2. Time Series Analysis Forecasts: These are based on the idea that past demand data can predict future demand. They can be further divided into four models: (1) Simple Moving Average, (2) Weighted Moving Average, (3) Exponential Smoothing, and (4) Linear Regression.

These distinctions help in understanding how forecasting can be applied to different scenarios and functions within operations and supply chain management.

The assumptions for CONWIP (Constant Work In Process) are: 1) single routing and 2) WIP (Work In Process) measured in units. 

In terms of modeling, CONWIP looks like a closed queueing network, similar to a pure pull system like Kanban, but with the distinction that in CONWIP, a job is allowed to enter the line each time a job leaves, maintaining a WIP level of 'm' jobs in the line at all times. 

This is different from a push system, where the WIP level is not directly observable, and the release rate must be set with respect to (unobservable) capacity. CONWIP, on the other hand, requires less WIP on average to attain the same throughput as a push system, and it facilitates working ahead of a schedule when favorable circumstances permit it.

The duration for a unit to travel through the process from start to finish is referred to as "throughput time." It includes process time (the time it takes to actually perform the work) and waiting time (the elapsed time from the time work is made available until it's completed and passed on to the next person or department in the chain).

The four basic work measurement techniques are:
1. Direct methods: Time study (using a stopwatch to time the work) and work sampling (recording random observations of a person or teams at work).
2. Indirect methods: Predetermined motion-time data system (summing data from tables of generic movement times developed in the laboratory to arrive at a time for the job) and elemental data (summing times from a database of similar combinations of movements to arrive at job time).

Goldratt's Rule 6 of Production Scheduling states that 'Bottlenecks govern both throughput and inventory in the system' (merged_src.pdf, page 241). This rule emphasizes the significant impact of bottleneck resources on the overall system performance, including throughput and inventory levels. Bottlenecks are the constraining factors in the system that limit the output rate, and they directly influence the system's ability to generate value (throughput) and manage work-in-progress (inventory).

On the other hand, Goldratt's Rule 3 states that 'Utilization and activation of a resource are not the same' (merged_src.pdf, page 240). This rule highlights the difference between a resource being activated (used) and being utilized (operating at full capacity). A resource can be activated without being fully utilized, as there might be idle time or underutilization. The key takeaway from Rule 3 is that resource utilization should be assessed concerning its impact on the system's constraints and overall performance.

The main difference between Rule 6 and Rule 3 lies in their scope and focus. Rule 6 addresses the system-wide implications of bottlenecks, while Rule 3 emphasizes the distinction between resource activation and utilization at the individual resource level. Both rules are interconnected, as the efficient use of non-bottleneck resources (Rule 3) can help improve the overall system performance by reducing the impact of bottlenecks (Rule 6).

Yes, I can help with that. Based on the provided documents, some key distinctions between services and goods are:

1. **Intangibility**: Services are intangible, meaning they cannot be touched or seen physically, while goods are tangible and have physical attributes.
2. **Customer Interaction**: Services require some interaction with the customer, as they are often produced and consumed simultaneously. Goods, on the other hand, are typically produced without the customer present and then sold, transferred, or distributed.
3. **Heterogeneity**: Services are inherently heterogeneous, meaning they can vary in quality and consistency even when provided under the same conditions. Goods, however, are generally more homogeneous, with less variation in quality and consistency.
4. **Perishability and Time Dependence**: Services are perishable and time dependent, meaning they cannot be stored for later use and must be provided at the time of demand. Goods, in contrast, can be stored and used at a later time.
5. **Package of Features**: Services are defined and evaluated as a package of features, including the service experience, the service provider, and any physical evidence of the service. Goods, conversely, are evaluated based on their physical attributes and features.

These distinctions are important in understanding the differences between operations and supply chain management for services and goods.
